publication.author: Cole, Donald. (University of Toronto, Canada); Lee-Smith, Diana; Nasinyama, George
publication.title: Healthy city harvests: Generating evidence to guide policy on urban agriculture
publication.Pub_Abstract: In an era of global urban food crises and rapid, unplanned city growth, how can urban agriculture be transformed from a potential source of health risks into a vehicle for healthier urban households and local environments? Embedded in the specific policy context of Kampala, Uganda, but relevant to the rest of Africa and beyond, this book provides research and evidence to guide policy about the health risks and benefits associated with urban farming.

publication.title: Farmer practices and adoption of improved potato varieties in Kenya and Uganda
publication.Pub_Abstract: This paper describes the potato production practices of Kenyan and Ugandan farmers and the level of adoption of improved potato varieties as of November 2005. The majority of these varieties are from materials derived from the International Potato Center (CIP).

publication.title: Sistematización de la implementaciónde las Escuelas de Campo deAgricultores (ECAs) en Andahuaylas
publication.Pub_Abstract: A partir del 2006, CESAL y el Centro de Promoción y Desarrollo Chanka (CEPRODECH) han venido implementando ECAs en los distritos de Santa María de Chicmo y Talavera de la Reina (provincia de Andahuaylas), con la asesoría y apoyo del Centro Internacional de la Papa y el financiamiento de la Junta de Comunidades de Castilla La Mancha. Esta publicación es el fruto de ese trabajo realizado los años 2006, 2007 y tiene como objetivo divulgar este tipo de metodología para que otros actores especialmente los agricultores pobres de la zona, puedan tomarla en consideración.

publication.author: Booth, Robert H.; Shaw, R.
publication.title: Principles of potato storage
publication.Pub_Abstract: This manual combines practical scientific and engineering information with the authors' potato storage experiences in many countries. Its purpose is to help scientists and technologists understand and solve potato storage problems. This publica­tion therefore considers some important socio­economic factors in addition to essential biological and engineering considerations. Basic storage principles appropriate to a wide range of storage needs under different circumstances are outlined and discussed.

publication.author: FAO, Rome (Italy).
publication.title: New light on a hidden treasure. International Year of the Potato 2008
publication.publisher: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
publication.Pub_Abstract: The review describes the rationale for the International Year of the Potato, its objectives and implementation. It introduces our guest-of-honour, solanum tuberosum, the humble tuber that spread form the Andes acros six continents and changed the course of world history. This book seeks to contirbute to strenghthening the potato industry everywhere.

publication.author: FAO, Rome (Italy).
publication.title: Nueva luz sobre un tesoro enterrado
publication.publisher: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
publication.Pub_Abstract: En la reseña se exponen las razones del Año Internacional de la Papa, sus objetivos y ejecucion. Se presenta nuestro invitado de honor, el Solanum tuberosum, el humilde tuberculo, que se propago desde los Andes hacia seis continentes y modifico el curso de la historia mundial. Este libro tiene como ojetivo contribuir al fortalecimiento de la industria de la papa en todo el mundo

publication.author: Ortiz, O. (CIP).; Pradel, Willy (CIP)
publication.title: Guía introductoria para la evaluación de impactos en programas de manejo integrado de plagas (MIP)
publication.Pub_Abstract: Esta guía pretende contribuir a llenar un vacío en la literatura relacionada con la evaluación del impacto de los proyectos de manejo integrado de plagas (MIP), y aunque está basada en experiencias realizadas en América Latina, podría ser adaptada a otras realidades. Lamentablemente, pocos proyectos de MIP han sido documentados de manera suficiente en términos del impacto alcanzado. Una de las razones es que la evaluación de impacto es una disciplina que no es ampliamente conocida. Pocos científicos sociales se han especializado en esta área. Además, en muchos casos los programas de MIP no incluyen a científicos sociales en sus equipos para apoyar el proceso de evaluación socioeconómica, debido a la falta de personal calificado, o a la falta de fondos para contratarlos. Esta guía es pues una valiosa herramienta para evaluar la rentabilidad de las inversiones en este tipo específico de investigación agrícola

publication.title: La crisis alimentaria: retos y oportunidades en los Andes
publication.series: Serie Contribuciones para el Desarrollo Sostenible de los Andes No 9, julio 2009
publication.Pub_Abstract: La conferencia electrónica: La crisis alimentaria: retos y oportunidades en los Andes permitió la reflexión regional sobre el impacto, los retos y las oportunidades que presenta la crisis alimentaria en los Andes y la potencialidad de los cultivos andinos.

publication.author: INCOPA; Centro Internacional de la Papa (CIP)
publication.title: Generando innovaciones para el desarrollo competitivo de la papa en el Peru
publication.Pub_Abstract: La investigación y el desarrollo tienen que ir de la mano para obtener impactos efectivos en los pequeños productores. Tal es el enfoque que aplica el Proyecto Innovación y Competitividad para la Papa Peruana (INCOPA) del Centro Internacional de la Papa. A través de su Enfoque Participativo de Cadenas Productivas involucra a todos los actores del proceso productivo del cultivo de papa con el fin de generar innovaciones que mejoren su competitivdad. En este documento se explica ese proceso y se dan ejemplos de cómo éste viene contribuyendo a mejorar los ingresos de los pequeños productores de las zonas andinas con la participación del sector empresarial.

publication.author: Bernet, T. (CIP).
publication.title: Past and present development of the peruvian dairy sector: A base document for further research
publication.Pub_Abstract: La prosperidad de los productores lácteos peruanos dependerá de la capacidad de los procesadores para competir con éxito contra los productos lácteos importados. A esa conclusión llega el presente estudio, luego de analizar los factores que influyen sobre los patrones de producción de estos productos y de los procesadores nacionales. Es una buena base de conocimientos para una investigación más produnda que fortalezca la competitividad de la producción y del procesamiento de leche en el Perú.

publication.author: Bucheli, Brenda; Ordinola, M. (CIP); Antezana, Ivonne; Maldonado, Luis. (CIP); Obregon, Celfia
publication.title: Estudio de caso: Evaluacion de impacto de la intervencion del Proyecto INCOPA/ADERS en Huanuco
publication.series: Ciencias Sociales. Documento de Trabajo No. 2009-2
publication.Pub_Abstract: This case-study investigates the effects related to the introduction of a participatory market chain approach among potato household farmers in Huánuco (Peru). The approach was initially promoted by the Association for Sustainable Development (ADERS) in 2002, and later by the INCOPA project (Innovation and Competitiveness of the Peruvian Potato). The two groups ultimately consolidated their work to further implement and disseminate the participatory market chain approach. The study arrives at several conclusions and recommendations of interest for those working with small farmers in identifying and exploiting new market opportunities.

publication.author: International Potato Center (CIP); Red Latinpapa,
publication.title: Catalogue of potato varieties and advanced clones
publication.Pub_SaleNote: For more information, please contact Dr Stefan de Haan
publication.Pub_Abstract: This catalogue is intended to provide relevant information about 170 advanced potato clones and 25 varieties developed at the International Potato Center (CIP). These clones and varieties are currently available for worldwide distribution to potato research programs and other interested parties, including national programs, universities, producer associations and farmer communities. The advanced clones and varieties listed in this catalogue combine several traits, such as resistance to late blight, viruses, high productivity, among others.

publication.author: Kroschel, Jurgen; Lawrence A. Lacey (editor),
publication.title: Integrated pest management for the potato tuber moth, Phthorimaea operculella (Zeller). A potato pest of global importance
publication.Pub_Abstract: The potato tuber moth, Phthorimaea operculella (Zeller), has achieved a worldwide distribution and is reported today to prevail in more than 90 countries. This publication is the result of a symposium on "Integrated Pest Management for the Potato Tuber Moth – A Potato Pest of Global Proportions", which was held as part of the 6th World Potato Congress, 21-24 August 2006, Boise, Idaho. The book presents and discusses in 12 papers pest status and new modeling tools for potato tuber moth forecasting and risk mapping, biocontrol with entomopathogens and parasitoids and the use of attracticides as well as integrated Pest Management for the potato tuber moth in various countries

publication.author: Low, J.W. (CIP).; Sub-Saharan Africa Regional Office, ; CIP
publication.title: SASHA: Sweetpotato Action for Security and Health in Africa
publication.Pub_Abstract: The International Potato Center's Sweetpotato Action for Security and Health in Africa (SASHA) project is aimed at improving food security and livelihoods for poor families in Sub-Saharan Africa by exploiting the, as yet untapped, potential of this highly nutritious crop. Sweetpotato requires fewer inputs and less labor than other staple crops. It tolerates harsh growing conditions and provides more edible energy per hectare per day than wheat, rice or cassava. The SASHA brochure explains how the project expects to directly impact the lives of at least 150,000 families in Sub-Saharan Africa over the next five years. A series of individual concise one page inserts explains the detail of the project. Various components cover such aspects as biotechnology and breeding, developing sustainable seed systems, how to integrate health and agriculture, and the development of market chains through public-private sector partnerships.

publication.author: Horton, D.; Prain, G. (CIP).; Thiele, G. (CIP).
publication.title: Perspectives on partnership: A literature review
publication.Pub_Abstract: Partnership is now considered an essential way of working in many fields and this literature review represents the first step in CIP's partnership research. The paper surveys contemporary literature useful for understanding and improving the roles of partnership and collaboration in the context of agricultural research for development. Conclusions and insights are grouped together from four distinct literatures: research studies; professional evaluation literature; practitioner-oriented reviews, guidelines and assessment tools; and CGIAR-related reviews, evaluations and policy documents. The paper also highlights gaps in current knowledge.

publication.title: La Ruta del Condor.A promising adaptation approach
publication.Pub_Abstract: The Ruta Condor microcenters offer the opportunity to study and save native varieties in their native environment, in situ, where they are exposed to the natural stresses of seasonal variation and climate change

publication.author: International Potato Center (CIP)
publication.title: Agriculture and soil carbon: Playing a major role in the mitigation of climate change
publication.Pub_Abstract: New advances developed jointly by the International Potato Center and the Brazilian Agricultural Research Corporation (EMBRAPA)have made it possible to measure, monitor, and verify soil carbon levels on site and develop soil protection strategies to mitigate the greenhouse effect caused by the release of carbon into the atmosphere

publication.author: International Potato Center (CIP)
publication.title: SPHI: Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative. Enhancing the lives of 10 million african families in 10 years
publication.Pub_Abstract: In 2009 the International Potato Center (CIP) launched a major new Sweetpotato for Profit and Health Initiative (SPHI). The 10-year multi donor initiative focuses on reducing child malnutrition and improving smallholder incomes through the effective production and expanded use of sweetpotato in Sub-Saharan Africa. Breeding for resistance and improved nutritional quality, the release of new varieties, participatory breeding with local farmers for improved variety development and evaluation, and farmer training programs are just some of the components of the initiative which brings together a number of collaborating institutes.

publication.author: Vernooy, Ronnie, IDRC; Nelles, Wayne, CIP; Campilan, Dindo, CIP; Li, Zhang, China
publication.title: Learning to evaluate capacity development and collaborative learning about community-based natural resource management: lessons from Asia
publication.Pub_Abstract: This paper, part of the Social Sciences Working Paper Series, presents studies undertaken by nine community-based, natural resource management (CBNRM)-oriented organizations in China, Viet Nam, the Philippines and Mongolia. The partner organizations, representing three broad types: academic, regional network, and community based, were brought together by a 2006 initiative in an informal network to develop and pilot methods for evaluating capacity development in community-based natural resource management. Each of the nine teams produced a comprehensive report on which this working paper is based. In a comparative analysis, the working paper addresses questions across the nine studies such as: what are various stakeholders learning from capacity development, and how can CBNRM capacity development be effectively monitored and evaluated.

publication.author: Njenga, Mary; Karanja, Nancy; Prain, G. (CIP).; Malii, John; Munyao, Patrick; Gathuru, Kuria; Mwasi, Beatrice
publication.title: Community-based energy Briquette production from urban organic waste at Kahawa Soweto Informal Settlement, Nairobi
publication.series: Urban Harvest Working Paper Series, Paper 5, October 2009
publication.Pub_Abstract: This Urban Harvest working paper, details an action research project undertaken by the Soweto Youth in Action (SOYIA) youth group in collaboration with Urban Harvest and Kenya Green Towns Partnership Association (Green Towns). Like many other large Sub-Saharan African cities, Nairobi faces the major challenges of environmental degradation and solid waste management. Whilst only 40% of the 2000 tonnes of solid waste the city generates daily is collected and disposed of, many of its urban poor lack affordable cooking fuel. Given that studies have shown that the majority of people rely on charcoal for cooking, this initiative aimed to generate income and provide employment in addition to making a crucial contribution to environmental management
